Award.AwardTitle: Dissertation Research: Nitrogen to phosporus ratio as a driver of arsenic retention
Award.AbstractNarration:
Arsenic is a trace element that can be toxic to people and at lower concentrations cause neurological symptoms or have immunological and endocrine effects. Throughout history, arsenic has been used as a poison, pesticide, weapon, and it has contaminated more than a billion-people's food and water supplies. In addition, a number of groundwater springs worldwide have naturally occurring arsenic levels that exceed those safe for human drinking water. As this groundwater seeps into streams the elevated arsenic can affect the chemistry and biology of the stream. This Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant (DDIG) research integrates arsenic into an ongoing study of streams in Ecuador to assess what drives arsenic retention in stream plants and animals and how that affects the transport of arsenic downstream. Understanding how arsenic interacts with other elements to cycle through water supplies will inform global mitigation efforts. Furthermore, the researchers will disseminate results to Ecuadorian communities reliant on arsenic contaminated waters.

Elevated stream arsenic concentrations can alter stream ecosystem function by altering the biogeochemical cycling of nitrogen and phosphorus or via altering aquatic food webs. In addition, the bioavailability and effects of arsenic on aquatic food webs are closely interlinked with both the concentrations of nitrogen and phosphorus and the ratio of nitrogen to phosphorus present in aquatic systems. Funds from this award will be used to evaluate how the nitrogen:phosphorus ratio of stream water affects the retention and transport of arsenic in geothermal streams with varying nitrogen:phosphorus ratios. The study also will test the effect of stream resource nitrogen:phosphorus ratio on arsenic cycling in the aquatic food web and biotic excreation of arsenic and consequent downstream transport.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview:  Throughout history, the trace element arsenic (As) has been famous for its use as a poison, pesticide, weapon, and its contamination of more than 200 million people's food and water supplies. In addition to the direct toxic effects to people, elevated stream As can alter ecosystem function. For example, As contamination decreases stream invertebrate abundance and diversity. Arsenic also affects cycling of common nutrients, like nitrogen (N) and phosphorus (P). Arsenic and P can share the same chemical structure in freshwater environments. Consequently, As can be taken into cells in place of P and decouple phosphorylation, hindering energy production. Recent research shows that organisms take up more As when P is low because, at low P, cells are less able to distinguish between As and P. In addition, microbial demand for P depends on the relative concentration of N. In previous research, the PIs' found that microbial As uptake depends on relative N:P, not just P concentration alone. The research extends this finding to evaluate how the relative N:P of stream water affects the retention and transport of As in geothermal streams, which are naturally high in As.

 The PIs measured the concentration of N, P, and As in the food web of three geothermal streams with varying N:P ratios. The PIs compared the elemental concentrations stored in basal resources and invertebrates from four functional feeding groups to test if streams with higher water N:P concentrations retain more As. The last objective of the proposed research focused on an additional ecosystem process, invertebrate excretion, to test the effect of resource N:P on release of As and consequent downstream transport.

Intellectual Merit: This project elucidated how trace elements interact with common elements to affect As retention and ecosystem functioning. Toxic trace elements and their relationship with other elements can drive biogeochemical cycles and have implications for global nutrient fluxes. Understanding how the relative amounts of As, N, and P affect As concentrations in stream food webs and stream processes will strengthen ecological stoichiometry as a framework for studying ecosystems and will be crucial for future research given the abundance of streams with elevated As.

We found that the N:P of water predicts As content of biofilms and fine particulate matter, likely because of microbial transformation decoupling the link between As and P cycling. We also found that the N:P of a resource is not a good predictor of invertebrate body content. Lastly, we found that resource N:P is not a good predictor of As or P excretion.           

Broader Impacts: Arsenic is linked to multiple cancers, neurological symptoms, lung and cardiovascular disease, and immunological and endocrine effects. Concentrations of As are above US EPA?s limit for drinking water in ~10% of US groundwater, and As affects more than a billion people worldwide. Understanding how As interacts with other elements to cycle through water supplies will help with global mitigation efforts. Furthermore, the PIs have established personal relationships with Ecuadorian communities and communicated their results to communities reliant on As contaminated waters.

The fieldwork was in collaboration with a multi-institution, collaborative project, including researchers and students at the Universidad de San Francisco-Quito. The fieldwork provided an opportunity for an Ecuadorian student to gain field and lab experience.
